awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Thermally Durable Plasmonic Near Field Transducer for Heat Assisted Magnetic Recording
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impacts/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project are to enable ultra-high capacity disk drives.  The explosion of global digital data and the need to store it is continuing to drive demand for disk storage.  Approximately 550 million drives are sold each year with a value of about $35B.  The greater storage densities created by heat assisted magnetic recording will drive down the cost of storage per Terabyte and greatly reduce the physical and thermal footprints in data centers.  A 10X greater drive capacity translates to an approximate 90% reduction in the number of drives required for any given storage requirement.  This will greatly reduce facility utility costs and emissions associated with housing, powering and cooling data centers.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to solve critical issues in heat assisted magnetic recording (HAMR) technology for next-generation of ultra-high capacity disk drives.   High data storage densities achievable with HAMR technology are expected to radically improve drive storage capacities through much greater densities. However, durable near field transducers (NFTs) are critical components that must be realized before commercialization of the devices is possible. Plasmonic materials with refractory properties are natural candidates for durable NFTs. In-depth comprehensive understanding of the connection between thermal cyclic load, oxidation, stoichiometry, crystalline structure and plasmonic properties for the plasmonic ceramics at nanoscale requires sufficient scientific and experimental support. Numerical simulations, optical characterization and advanced electron microscopy techniques will be employed to investigate the performance of plasmonic ceramics with refractory properties as reliable NFTs for HAMR technology.

por.por_cntn:
The computer hard disk drive (HDD) industry has been struggling to realize the next generation of ultra-high capacity disk drives. HDD capacities have plateaued since 2011 even as the volume of data generated grows exponentially. In magnetic recording technology, achieving higher data storage densities requires the reduction of bit sizes, which brings new challenges such as the loss of data in very small grains due to thermal instabilities. Materials with higher magnetic anisotropy can be used as a solution; however this requires higher field strengths. A solution to the problem is heat assisted magnetic recording (HAMR). The greater storage densities created by HAMR will drive down the cost of storage per Terabyte and greatly reduce the physical and thermal footprints in data centers. A 10X greater drive capacity translates to an approximate 90% reduction in the number of drives required for any given storage requirement. This will greatly reduce facility and utility costs and the carbon emissions associated with housing, powering and cooling data centers.

Heat assisted magnetic recording technology imposes local high temperatures concentrated around the magnetic grains. Nanometer-scale metallic antennas are used for localization of energy down to a few tens of nanometers. These metal nano-antennas fail to survive under the harsh operating environment of HAMR devices and experience structural deformations as well as optical property degradation. In this project, we developed ceramic materials that can optically perform similar to metal nano-antennas but exhibit refractory properties (meaning durable at high temperatures under harsh conditions) that enables longer operation periods. An ideal nano-antenna for HAMR operation shall focus the incident light on to a magnetic grain without any loss inside the antenna. Although this is not completely avoidable, reduction of antenna self-heating improves the device quality. Reduced self-heating can be achieved by a reduction of the absorption of the incident light inside the antenna. We have investigated several ceramic materials to identify promising candidates and optimized their optical properties to reduce absorption. An optimized nano-antenna shall be able to dissipate the heat built inside its volume in order to avoid excessive heating that would damage the neighboring elements. Thus, the antenna material shall have large thermal conductivity. The refractory ceramics developed in this work have thermal conductivities much larger than the previously reported bulk properties for this material class and show potential for efficient dissipation of heat. Routes for lower temperature deposition of these materials were investigated for process compatibility.
